_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water.  The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination.  Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water.  The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) also stores and uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards.  Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations.  LADWP takes safety obligations in storing and using chlorine as seriously as it takes providing safe drinking water.  LADWP has been operating the Upper Stone Canyon (USC) Chlorination Station since 1986, which is a chlorination facility that stores and uses anhydrous chlorine for disinfection purposes.  LADWP decided to make significant improvements to the existing chlorination facility to further enhance the safety and offsite consequences of an accidental chlorine release.  The modified chlorination facility is in operation since 2008.  The modified Upper Stone Canyon chlorination station chlorine handling process is also subject to the U.S. environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk management Program and Plan, and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulations.  EPA and CalARP regulations require the preparation and five year update of the Risk Management Plan for facilities subject to federal EPA and CalARP regulations. An update is required at least once every five years from the date of its initial submission.  An update is also required within six months of a change that alters the Program Level that applied to any covered process.

The RMP is to include policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility and the actions which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency. A Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination

Station was prepared in June 1999 that was updated in June 2004 and November 2007.  The Risk Management Plan and Program for the modified chlorination facility was prepared in September 2008.  LADWP prepared Program Level 2 RMPs from 1999 through 2008 because Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station is not subject to PSM regulations. However, in the excess of caution, LADWP has now decided to prepare a Program Level 3 RMP. Thus, this 2010 update of the Risk Management Plan for the Upper Stone Canyon facility demonstrates compliance with the Program Level 3 requirements.  It should be noted that no changes have been made to the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station after the preparation of the September 2008 Risk Management Plan.

The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary:

A?    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
A?    General facility and regulated substances information.
A?    Offsite consequence analysis results.
A?    Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
A?    Five-year accident history summary.
A?    Emergency response program summary.
A?    Planned changes to improve safety.

The above information for the Upper Stone Canyon chlorination station is provided below.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The LADWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable requirements of the State of California and EPAA?s Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

The LADWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community

, and is in compliance with the EPA and CalARP Program Emergency Response Program Requirements.  The LADWP has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The emergency response plan has been coordinated with local response agencies (City of Los Angeles Fire Department). 

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information

The Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station is located at 15000 A? Mulholland Drive in Los Angeles, California.  The station serves to disinfect drinking water by chlorinating water in the reservoirs and at various locations in the on-site water piping system.  The treated waters are piped into the distribution network, which serves parts of west Los Angeles with potable water.  The station building consists of a chlorine storage room, chlorine equipment room, an electrical equipment room, several chemical storage rooms, and a dry media scrubber room.  The facility stores chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the EPA and CalARP Program rules.  Chlorine containers can be connected to the chlorination process to feed chlorine liquid or gas.  The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the EPA and CalARP rules.  It also exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the federal and California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards.  However, the facility is normally unmanned and water treatment operators visit the facility daily and respond to any trouble alarms, which may occur.  Thus, the LADWP Upper Stone Canyon facility is not subject to federal or California OSHA PSM regulations.
The design incorporates two banks of chlorine containers, which normally feed liquid chlorine to evaporators.  There is an automatic switcho

ver system that determines which liquid chlorine header feeds the evaporators.  This system consists of a control panel, two motorized ball valves, and a pressure switch on the liquid header before the evaporators.  When the pressure in the liquid chlorine supply line drops to 20 psi, the switchover system opens the valve isolating the standby bank of chlorine containers to allow liquid chlorine to flow.  At the same time, it closes the ball valve on the now empty bank of chlorine containers.

The system is also configured with gas headers for each of the two banks of chlorine containers.  This is a complete gas feed system with automatic switchover capability.  It can be used during periods of low chlorine demand, or if the liquid system is out of service for maintenance or repairs.  It is provided to support a wide range of operations at this site.

Since the normal operation is by withdrawing liquid chlorine, and the evaporators are equipped with motorized vacuum regulating valves downstream, it is possible for the gas supply to the chlorinators to be automatically shut off at the vacuum-regulating valve.  These valves can close upon a low temperature condition in the evaporator or at the valve, or upon power failure.  For this reason, in order to assure no interruptions of chlorine feed, a third bank of chlorine containers is provided.  These containers connect to a gas header which leads to automatic switchover type vacuum regulating valves acting as an automatic backup gas supply.  The valves open automatically based on a high vacuum condition that pulls the valve out of its detent position.

A dry media type chlorine gas scrubber system is installed at the station.  The unit is actuated by chlorine detectors at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm.  The scrubber is provided to neutralize an accidental release of chlorine gas from the chlorine storage or chlorinator rooms.  The scrubber draws suction from the chlorine storage and chlorinator rooms through a duct.

The station is equipped with an uninterruptible power supply (UPS) in addition to a backup power generator.  Therefore, in case of the failure of regular power, the scrubber will remain functional.

All on-line containers are equipped with automatic closure valve actuators on the chlorine container valves.  These actuators close the valves when any of the chlorine gas sensors in the chlorine tank or chlorinator rooms detect gas exceeding 3 ppm.  The scrubber system starts simultaneously.

The emergency backup gas supply is equipped with automatic closure valve actuators as well, but they do not close automatically upon sensing a chlorine leak.  They remain open until an operator on site presses one of the red mushroom switches located at the exit doors.  This is necessary to protect against loss of disinfection to the distribution system.  Even if the emergency backup gas supply was the source of an accidental chlorine gas release, the total capacity of these containers is less than what the scrubber system is designed to handle. 

The gaseous chlorine from the evaporators or from the chlorine gas headers proceeds to the chlorinators that regulate the flow of chlorine.  Chlorine gas from the chlorinators is pulled by vacuum to injectors mostly located in underground vaults.  The injectors provide vacuum, which draws chlorine gas into mixing water to form a concentrated solution.  The solution is then piped through diffusers into the reservoirs or various locations in the on-site water piping system.

Seven chlorine leak sensors are provided in the station to detect chlorine leaks.  The sensors are located in the chlorine container and chlorinator rooms, as well as from the scrubber inlet and outlet ducts.  The detectors signal an alarm by activating a flashing red light over the entry door to the building, as well as an audible alarm within the container and chlorination rooms, and activating an alarm at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) at Sylmar.

Also, the chlorine injector vaults are equipped with chlorine leak sensors.

Process control is by a programmable controller, which determines the feed rate based on the water flow rate and the chlorine residual.  There are flow meters transmitting flow signals to the controller.  Chlorine residual analyzers continuously monitor the treated water residuals.

In the event power is lost at the chlorine facilities, an alarm will alert the LAAFP control room.  Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences.
The facility is normally unmanned; water treatment operators visit the facility daily. A response team coordinated from LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) responds to any trouble alarms, which may occur. Access to the facility is through gates, which are kept locked all the time.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The LADWP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

A?    Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
A?    Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
A?    Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
A?    Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
A?    Use of industry recommended process and safety equipment.
A?    Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
A?    High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
A?    Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, presence of chlorine de

tectors with remote monitoring, the use of automatic closure actuators on the on-line chlorine container valves, a chlorine main scrubber, and a chlorine mini-scrubber (currently not in operation).

Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and MSDS sheets.

Equipment safety information was compiled on the chlorine process. Specifications for the chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facility are on file at the facility.  LADWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Process Hazard Analysis/Hazard Review

A hazard review/process hazard analysis of the modified Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station was performed in March 2002 after the system design was completed.  A review of the March 2002 hazard review/process hazard analysis was performed on August 1, 2008, which included the review for the modified chlorination system equipment and procedures. The process hazard analysis review will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there is major change in the process. A list of recommended actions was developed in August 2008 to further improve the chlorine safety.  All recommendations have been evaluated and implemented by LADWP staff.

Seismic design of the chlorination station building was based on the 1999 version of the City of Los Angeles Building Code, which incorporates the 1997 Uniform Building Code.  Also considered were the site-specific response spectra for the project.  A memo dated November 13, 20

06 from the LADWP Civil/Structural Engineering Design Group describes how the design complies with the January, 2004 CalARP seismic guidance document.  The seismic design criteria related to the equipment installation was included in the construction specifications.  Contractor submittals were required and included evaluations of meeting the seismic design criteria.  Each submittal was reviewed by LADWP Engineering personnel to make sure the proposed equipment installation met the seismic design requirements.  Seismic concerns were therefore incorporated into the design and as each piece of equipment was evaluated for installation.  No additional recommended actions resulted from the engineering review or from the seismic walkthrough performed in February, 2007.

Operating Procedures

LADWP has prepared written operating procedures for Upper Stone Canyon chlorination facility that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination process. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information. Written operating procedures included in the facilityA?s Operation and Maintenance Manual include:

A?    Delivery of Chlorine
A?    Container Connections 
A?    Initial Startup Procedure 
A?    Normal Operation 
A?    Normal Shutdown 
A?    Temporary Operations 
A?    Emergency Operations 
A?    Emergency Shutdown 
A?    Startup Following Emergency Shutdown 

Training 

The LADWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination process, and each employee newly assigned to this process, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above. The LADWP employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination process.  The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  Employee

training includes as a minimum the following elements:

A?    Safety Information.
A?    Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.
A?    Maintenance Procedures.
A?    Operating Procedures for the chlorine system.
A?    RMP Program contents.
A?    Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.

Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, LADWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after major modifications.  Training programs for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station were most recently reviewed on August 4, 2009.

Contractors

LADWP Contractor procedures specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on or near the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  LADWP provides information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes. 

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

LADWP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the chlorination systems that require a MOC procedure implementation.  The required conditions prior to startup include:

A?    Construction and/or equipment are in accordance with design specifications.
A?    Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.
A?    A PHA has been performed for any new facilities and recommendations have been resolved or implemented prior to startup.
A?    At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.
A?    Training of each operating and maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.

These procedures ensure that no ne

w/significantly modified process will start-up and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process prior to the pre-startup safety review.  This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately addressed.  This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 

Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance personnel.

Maintenance 

The LADWP operates a computerized maintenance management program that generates a task order for performance of the preventive maintenance routine at pre-determined intervals based on the type of equipment.  A description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order.  The water treatment supervisor is responsible for this task.  

In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the Operation and Maintenance Manual as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize inspection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, bi-monthly, monthly, biannual, annual, every 2 to 10 years, and as-needed basis.  These allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary.  The schedules are supplemental to the log sheets on-site and provide a summary and quick reference to manufacturer's O&M manuals.  A maintenance log book is provided on-site for quick reference by the Operator. 

LADWP documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorination equipment and assures the performance is done in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups (i.e., Chlorine Institute).

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operat

ions.  The procedures call for the issuance of a hot work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorination process and other areas deemed appropriate as described in the procedures.  Fire prevention and protection systems are in place prior to the issuance of the hot work permit.  The permit indicates the dates the work is authorized for, the location and specific operational requirements and is kept on file in the administrative office. 

LADWP Management of Change (MOC) procedures include steps required to be taken by plant personnel prior to implementing changes to chlorination equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions.  Training, PSI, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are updated according to the changes made.

Internal Compliance Audits

The LADWP has been certifying at a minimum of every three years that compliance with Program 2 Prevention Program requirements is met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. Starting April 2010, compliance audits will seek to verify compliance with Program 3 Prevention Program requirements. 

The compliance audit consists of separating the RMP program elements or sections, and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness.  For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Certification Page and Compliance Audit Checklist forms (one form for each preventive program requirement).  The Compliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader.  The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contains questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:

A?    Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.
A?    On-Site Conditions: The audit team will review the program elements based on observation of the

plant conditions and safety practices.
A?    Interviews:  The program elements will be evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.

Team members record RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.

Incident Investigation

The LADWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel.  The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event.  The LADWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and shall implement the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence.  All incident investigation reports are retained on LADWP file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.

Five-year Accident History Summary

An accidental minor chlorine release occurred at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station in April, 2007.  This accident occurred inside the chlorinator room and one operator suffered from chlorine gas inhalation.  The operator was treated for chlorine inhalation.  There were no onsite or offsite deaths.  Also, there were no offsite injuries and no evacuation actions were required.

Emergency Response Program Summary

LADWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental releases.  In the event an accidental release that could result in offsite consequences occurs, external resources such as the City of Los Angeles Fire Department will be solicited to respond as well.  

As part of the emergency response program, the LADWP has developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.  The following elements are included:

(a)    An emergency response plan, maintained at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station and at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:
A?    Organizati

onal structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various LADWP personnel.
A?    Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.
A?    Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorination process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of LADWP personnel who respond to chlorine releases.
A?    Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the LADWP.
A?    Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.
A?    Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.
A?    Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.
(b)    Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 
(c)    Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorination process.
(d)    Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As part of updating the Risk Management Program for the Upper Stone Canyon chlorination station, a hazard review/process hazard analysis of the modified chlorination system was performed on August 1, 2008.  The hazard review/process hazard analysis was performed using the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) technique and covered equipment and main procedures used for the chlorination process.  All the recommendations made based on the process hazard analysis have been evaluated and implemented.
